titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. VII:15. I found my self this morning far from well; but so much better than I was last Evening that I was able to go out; and at 11. O’Clock went with Mrs Adams to the Roman Catholic Maltese Chapel, and attended the funeral obsequies of Madame de Bardaxi-Azara, to which we had been invited by her husband. The Chapel was full and all the foreign Ministers were there, excepting the Duke de Serra-Capriola, who is unwell. On my return home I found a note from Count Romanzoff requesting me to call on him at 9. O’Clock this Evening at his house on the English Quay. I went accordingly at that hour. The Count said that as he was on the point of abdicating, he wished to persevere untill the last in the habits which he had formed and constantly observed with me, and would therefore shew me the dispatch from Count Lieven, which he had received yesterday by a Courier from the Emperor’s Head-Quarters— He then put it into my hands—it was numbered 260. dated 26. November/8 December 1813. and marked that a duplicate was sent to Count Nesselrode. It stated that the British Government having been informed of the definitive refusal by the American Ministers at St: Petersburg to negotiate directly with them for Peace, on account of the limitation of their powers to a Negotiation under the Emperor’s Mediation, Lord Castlereagh had communicated to him Count Lieven, that in order to avoid some of the delays which would arise from waiting untill the Envoys could write to their Government for further Instructions and Powers, he himself had just written to Mr: Monroe, proposing to him to send his Instructions through the medium of Sir John Warren, and explaining the motives upon which Great-Britain had declined treating with the United States under a Mediation.— That as this measure had been taken at a period so splendid for England, it would prove to the Emperor of Russia that they entered cordially into his views, in the disposition to terminate a War—which they considered as not conformable to the Interests of the British Nation— The Count asked me if I had already received information of this— I had not— He had supposed it might have been communicated to me by Lord Walpole— I had seen him this Morning, but he had said nothing of it to me.— The Count told me that he had received no other Communication upon this subject from the Emperor or from Count Nesselrode— That the Courier who brought it to him had also brought an immense number of Packets, addressed to him which had been accumulating there for several weeks; but not even the Ratifications of the Peace with Persia; the term for exchanging which was already past.— Mr Harris had been with him this Evening; and had told him he should call upon him again to take leave. Mr: Gallatin had written to him at the time of his departure, requesting him to write to them whatever might occur after their departure in reference to the Mission. Mr Harris had offered this Evening to take his letters— He would write with pleasure to Mr Gallatin, as an Evidence how much he valued his correspondence— But he had told Mr Harris and Mr Gallatin himself must be sensible that as Chancellor of the Empire, after the departure of those Gentlemen he must consider their Mission as terminated, and could write nothing to them concerning it— Nor could he have any occasion to regret this, since I was here to whom he should naturally make every proper Communication of business, and who would of course transmit all the material information to them— He had therefore not mentioned this dispatch this Evening to Mr Harris, because I was the person to whom he thought proper to make it known. When Mr Dallas went from hence, Mr Gallatin had asked him the Count to recommend him to the Ambassador Count Lieven, and to hear what he should say to him, respecting the State of our Negotiation here— He had accordingly strongly recommended Mr Dallas to Count Lieven, and with much pleasure, as he knew it would procure to the Count an agreeable acquaintance. And the Count had informed him that he had received Mr Dallas with pleasure— I said I hoped he was not in earnest in what he had said and repeated several times about abdicating— Altogether in earnest he said— He had more than once written to the Emperor requesting him to accept his Resignation. On the occasion of sending to him the Treaty of Peace with Persia, he had reviewed the request. The Emperor had answered him, that he justly appretiated the high and honourable character, and the importance of this Treaty—and concluded by saying—“Il y a dans la derniere ligne de votre lettre une idée à la quelle je ne puis pas me faire.”— Upon which, said the Count, I have replied to the Emperor, insisting upon my resignation; and recalling to his recollection that after the Peace of Tilsit, with which I had nothing to do, when he laid his commands upon me to take the Department of foreign Affairs he told me that he had then two Wars upon his hands; that with Turkey and that with Persia; and had just contracted the engagement of commencing two others; with Sweden, and with England— These four Wars are now all brought to a termination; the Peace with Persia closes the last of them; it
brings to a natural conclusion all the business upon which I came into Office, and affords to the Emperor an opportunity to dismiss me, “avec bonté.”— I have in truth now, no other business to do— The Emperor when he went away determined to write to me upon business, exclusively, himself— He has entered upon other business, other engagements— He not only commands his own army, but oversees and superintends the interest of all the Allies— Insensibly he has dropped the habit of writing to me at-all. His time is absorbed; he is always intending to write me in one or two days— Multitudes of letters come from the Head-Quarters upon business saying that the orders on this that and the other affair will certainly be dispatched to me in one or two days; and the orders never come. I have nothing to do. To be Chancellor of the Empire for the sake of signing Passports, and giving answers about law-suits is not worth-while—and yet, the office keeps me here in a state of perpetual subjection— I cannot sleep out of St: Peterburg; I cannot attend to my private affairs— I cannot visit my own Estates, which I very much desire to do— I therefore intreat the Emperor to give me my discharge, and leave me to bless him for all his favours, and to wish him all happiness and Prosperity.— I expect now every day to receive the Emperor’s acceptance of my Resignation— It is not more than four or five days since it would have been possible by the course of time that I should have received it— Now, it may come every hour, and an answer must be given to my application— I told the Count that I could not but express my personal regret at his determination— He said that as to his personal sentiments they would always remain the same; but he must do as his old Grandmother told him once after she was turned of eighty, told him she was resolved to do— After two years more, she told him she was determined to turn over a new leaf; to change entirely her course of life; and to go and live at Moscow— I, said the Count am not quite so old, as my Grandmother was then; but I am sixty; and have not so good health as she had— I shall not wait two years to turn over my new leaf— My feelings are entirely American (Je puis dire que j’ai les Entrailles Américaines) and were it not for my age and infirmities I would go now that that Country. In the whole of this Conversation there was not a syllable uttered by the Count in the nature of complaint— His tone was altogether that of cheerfulness and pleasantry— The wounded Spirit was only to be seen in the allusion to the four Wars, of which he reminded the Emperor, and which hung upon him when the Count entered upon his office— All these Wars have been closed honourably; three of them gloriously for Russia during the Count’s Administration—the Commemoration of them must carry a Reproach to the Emperor’s Heart; but it indicates a proud consciousness in the Count of his own Services; and a firm and independent Spirit in referring to them.— He said that from the commencement of the New-Year he had removed from the Hotel of the Department of foreign Affairs to his own house, and was there quietly waiting for his discharge— I spoke to him about the translations of the official documents concerning our War with England, which he had promised me should be published in the Gazettes, and which afterwards at his request I had consented to leave unpublished, untill the determination of the British Government on the offer of Mediation should be known— He said he thought that after this new step of England towards a direct Negotiation, there was still the same reason to avoid the publication—to forbear from all irritating acts— That if I absolutely insisted upon it, they should be published, but Lord Walpole had already reproached him for what he had published, concerning the American Mission, and any such publication at this time would be entirely imputed to him— This is certainly true; and it might in the present state of things, be of such consequences to him personally that I concluded not to insist upon the publication— I told him that as he placed the matter upon the ground of a personal favour to him, I should say no more; but that he had formally and repeatedly promised me the publication should take place— That I had asked it, because the English documents, to which these were answers had been previously published in the same Papers— That the Emperor had declared himself neutral, between the United States and England— That he had offered them his Mediation, which the United States had accepted— They had not merited any act of his Government indicating partiality against them; and if I consented now not positively to demand the publication of these Papers, I should at least not expect to see any more extracts from the English Newspapers, concerning their War with us, injurious to my Country and its Government— That such paragraphs did even now appear; He asked in what paper— I named the Invalid— He said he had no controul over that Paper; though it was under the controul of the Police— That the Papers under his direction were the political part of the St: Petersburg Gazette; Russian and German; and the whole of the Conservateur Impartial— That there was a paragraph in that of this day, stating that there had been a bloody Battle in Canada, in which 300 English had totally defeated 8000 Americans— It had appeared to him ridiculous and self-contradictory—a bloody Battle and 300 men was a contradiction in terms— But it was merely an extract from an article in a German Gazette— I told him I had been going to mention that very article to him, together with that in the Invalid— He said that he would to-morrow give orders,
that nothing respecting the War between America and England should be published in either of those Papers, excepting the mere statement of military Events.— On my return home from the Count’s I found Mr Lewis, who passed the remainder of the Evening with us untill Midnight. Mr de Tracy and Mr de Castres had been here earlier, but were gone.

2. VII. I wrote this morning a Note to Count Romanzoff requesting a Copy of the Dispatch from Count Lieven which he shewed me last Evening, or a particular statement of its Contents. Mr Montreal called on me and finished the transaction of the draft upon Mr Samuel Williams in London. Montreal is in deep affliction and indignation at the Speeches of the Emperor Napoleon, and of the Senators which have just been published, and which prove the desperation of the Circumstances in which France is placed beyond all possibility of doubt. Mr Harris came and brought me my Book, of papers relating to the Mission Extraordinary. He confirmed what Count Romanzoff told me last Evening; that Mr Gallatin upon leaving this City had put into his hands, together with some other Papers, a letter to Count Romanzoff, the contents of which had been unknown to him. That the Count last Evening had told him that it contained a request from Mr Gallatin, that he the Count would write to him, and transmit to him any official document that he might receive from the Emperor relative to the Mission—and urging the ill effects it would have in America, if the Envoys should return without any further Communication from His Majesty. That the Count had desired Mr Harris to tell Mr Gallatin, that he would with pleasure write to him about La playe et le Beau Temps; but that he, Mr Gallatin, must himself be aware that from the moment of his departure from St: Petersburg, the Chancellor of the Empire, could no longer write to him upon subjects relating to the Mission— That I was the person through whom the Communication were to be made, and to whom alone he could write.— Harris says that Mr Gallatin’s expectation is confident of a re-appointment upon the new Commission for a direct Negotiation. I dined with Mr Slade, at Mr Lewis’s. Dr Beresford, Mr Swistounoff, a Prince Yousoupoff and another Russian Gentlemen, with Mr Smith were of the Company.— Evening at home.

3. V:30. Employed all the morning in preparing dispatches and letters to be sent by Mr Harris— Mr Lewis called upon me, this forenoon— I received a letter from Mr Beasley in London— The news from America this day is mortifying.— Messrs: Raimbert, Montréal, the two Consolats and Peyron, De Tracy and De Castres, Lewis and Slade, and Dr Beresford dined with us. As they went away, Mr Harris came in, and passed the rest of the Evening with us, untill near Midnight. Dr: Galloway was here, and I gave him the two notes for him from Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard, which Mr Gallatin left with me, and which he said contained money. Mr de Castres told me that Mr Barbé-Marbois had been his Guardian, and mentioned several Circumstances concerning him, and his family. I enquired of Mr Peyron, concerning his father and family.— I had known him here in the years 1781 and 1782. living with Mr Raimbert’s elder brother; and being then Swedish Consul.— The last time I saw him was at Hamburg in 1797. he was then Swedish Minister there— He is now living in the neighbourhood of Stockholm.

4. VII:15. I am in such a state of health, that my system of early rising yields to it. Mr Harris called upon me this morning, and told me that he should postpone his departure, untill next Tuesday— He brought me my letter Book, of the joint Mission, to which some Additions, are still to be made— I told him that before he went away there were two subjects, upon which I thought it best to have some explanation, with him— The first was to enquire whether he had formed a commercial connection with Mr Lawrence Brown, an English merchant in this place; and if he had, whether he considered it as compatible with the office of Secretary to a legation for negotiating Peace. He said he had not—that Mr Norman had formed, or was forming some such connection with Mr Brown, though he had told him this morning there were some difficulties in it, of which they had not been aware. That he himself had told Mr Brown that he could not think of any such connection previous to the Peace; but as Mr Brown had been unfortunate and was a very worthy man, he had promised him that if the connection between Mr Norman and him should take place, he, Harris upon returning to America would do every thing in his power, to promote their Interests of a commercial Nature. For he assured me that he did consider any commercial connection, with a British subject as altogether incompatible with the Office of Secretary to the Legation— I told him I was satisfied with his positive Assurance that he had formed no such connection— That I had asked the question not for the sake of prying into his private concerns, but because I had heard he had formed a partnership with Mr Brown; and had the fact been so, I thought my duty to the Public required me to give him my opinion that such a connection was not compatible with the Office of a Secretary to such a Legation, or
at least, that during the existence of the Legation, it would interdict all correspondence whatsoever between him and his partners. He said he was fully sensible of that, and had declined any connection of that sort with Mr Brown, and before that, with Mr Lewis— The second object of my enquiry was whether Mr Bayard had ever said any thing to him with regard to my dispositions towards him— He said Mr Bayard had once said to him—“Mr Harris; I have reason to believe Mr Adams is no friend of yours.” that he, Harris had asked him upon what grounds he had formed such an opinion—that he had avoided particularizing, but had repeated, he had very good reason to believe I was not friendly to him; or that he was no favourite in my family— All he would say further was, that I did not like Harris’s Politics, and that my motive for being unfriendly to him was that he was the Secretary to the Extraordinary Mission, instead of my Nephew— Harris said that these suggestions had given him great pain—that excepting on one occasion which he had hoped would be forgotten, he was conscious of never having given me occasion to be unfriendly to him—that as to his Politics, he could have none but those which favoured the interests of his Country; and that he had taken no step whatsoever to obtain the Office of Secretary to the Legation— I told him that I would deal with him in perfect Candour— It was possible that in Conversation with Bayard, I might at sometime have lightly said Harris is more of a Russian, or takes more pleasure in the success of the Allies than I do— But that I had certainly never said any thing to him which could warrant him in making the inference that I was unfriendly to him; and that his imputation of the motive was as false as the insinuation itself. That I had never wished that my Nephew should have had the appointment of Secretary to this Mission; and if I had, I should never have been unfriendly to him, Harris, because he had been preferred— Mr Bayard and I had formerly been in strong opposition to each other in the Senate of the United States— When he came here one of my most earnest wishes was to harmonize with him— I had uniformly treated him with respect and attention— There had been no misunderstanding or variance between us; but he had repeatedly made attempts to injure Mr Gallatin in my opinion; and I had now reason, since their departure to believe that he had made similar attempts against me upon the mind of Mr Gallatin— I should feel a stronger resentment against him for this, had I not found that tale-bearing and strife-stirring was so congenial to Mr Bayard’s character that he applied it to others as well as myself, and exerted it impartially against all his acquaintance— That he was addicted to intemperate habits, and when his wine worked upon his natural temper its uniform operation was to set his tongue to mischief-making.— Harris said it was all too true— That he had entertained a very exalted idea of Bayard’s character before he came here; that it had sunk now so low that he was ashamed of him as a Countryman.— That during the latter part of the time that he had been here, he was almost every evening so intoxicated that he had made himself the scorn of his own Servants, and of the People of the house where he lived; and that the very night when he went away he got into his carriage in a condition fit for nothing but to go to bed— That he had quarreled with Milligan, which had been the occasion of Milligan’s leaving him. That he had asked him Harris, to speak to Milligan, and effect a reconciliation between them—that he had spoken to Milligan, accordingly, but without success— That Milligan was so exasperated with what he thought Bayard’s ill treatment of him, that he would listen to nothing; and that he made no scruple of saying that he considered Bayard as a common Sot— I said I had heard that Bayard had reported to him, something said of him by Mr Gallatin; with which he would naturally be displeased— He said that one morning, Bayard said to him, Mr Harris; Milligan will tell you some Conversation we had last Evening about you—that he had asked Milligan what it was—that Milligan had endeavoured for some time to put him off, and said it was all mere joking— But on Harris’s insisting, he had said that Mr Gallatin the Evening before, at supper, being warm with wine, (which Harris said he had never observed Gallatin to be, but which Milligan told him he certainly had been at that time) had said something about Harris and women; a mere trifle which he Milligan told it, was nothing; but that Bayard himself had afterwards told it to him, and given it a turn, which was certainly displeasing— Harris was not more explicit— But the Conversation was this— Bayard asked Gallatin, why Harris did not visit more intimately at Princess Michel Galitzin’s— Gallatin answered that the Princess was a woman of too much sense to take notice of such men as Harris— “No, Sir—it is such men as me; that Princess Michel, distinguishes by her notice”— And this was the speech of Gallatin’s that Bayard was so studious of reporting to Harris; that he first set Milligan to make the report, and finding he had not made it malignant enough, took care to make it so himself.— Another of Bayard’s good offices to Gallatin was this— Dining one day at Mr Krehmer’s where there was a mixed company, among whom was Gisborne and some other Englishmen, Bayard said he would tell them of a debate which
once took place in the House of Representatives of the United States, when they were both members of that body— It was upon a Bill for raising Troops, and a member of Gallatin’s party had called them mercenaries; at which some offence had been taken by members on the other side— That Gallatin to justify his fellow partizan had said that the term mercenary did not imply any thing offensive; that it signified only persons paid for their services— That soldiers might properly be called mercenaries, because they were paid— And in the same sense there were mercenary Divines, mercenary Physicians, and mercenary lawyers— Upon which, said Bayard, I rose and said that [“]the Gentleman in his list of mercenaries had forgotten to enumerate the mercenary Patriots— Foreigners, who came into the Country; ever declaiming about patriotism, and ever ready to sell themselves to the highest bidder.” Lewis was present at this dinner; but had left the table and the dining-Room with the Ladies, before Bayard told the Story— But immediately afterwards Gisborne came into the Room, and said—there—we have always heard that Gallatin was a venal frenchman, and now we have it from his own Colleague— And then repeated the whole Story as Bayard had told it.— He told it over a fortnight afterwards again to Harris—upon which Harris said he had thought it his duty to speak to Bayard.— He reminded him that Bayard had once said to him “Mr Harris; as we are not likely to make a Treaty here for our Government, I should like to make a Treaty of friendship with you.” That he had accepted the proposition with much pleasure and gratitude, and would now perform an act of friendship to him; by advising him to be cautious, in what manner he spoke of his Colleague in mixed companies— He then told him what he had heard from Gisborne; and said he must be aware that such things, said in such Company were very apt to be reported two days afterwards to the Court. Mr Bayard he said had taken his advice in good part; and appeared to be sensible of his own indiscretion. I observed to Harris that I hoped never again to be placed in relations which would make it necessary to associate with Mr Bayard— But as I possibly might, and should have every reason to expect a continuance of his favours like those I had learnt of since his departure, I asked of him, Harris, that if Bayard should ever again, report or insinuate any thing to him, the tendency of which was to excite enmity or dissension between us, he would immediately inform me of it, and give me the opportunity of clearing it up— He solemnly promised that he would— I told him that I neither asked nor wished him ever to tell me any thing else, that Bayard might say to him of me; for I cared very little what a man capable of such conduct said or thought of me.— I added that I had found no difficulty in getting along with Mr Gallatin; and excepting his last letter to Count Romanzoff, requesting the Count to correspond with him on business of the Mission, which the Count as well as myself had thought a little singular, I had no cause to complain of him— Perhaps he might explain that— I had a much higher opinion of Mr Gallatin’s abilities than of Mr Bayard’s— Mr Bayard was an eloquent Speaker in a popular Assembly; but of his abilities for any thing else, I had seen little evidence here— Mr Gallatin’s had struck me very powerfully in our Conferences with Count Romanzoff— In his Note upon the Impressment of Seamen—and in his letter to Mr Baring— Harris agreed with me, and said he had been surprized to see how weak and clumsy the Papers drawn up by Bayard were.— Gallatin he said had uniformly spoken well of me to him; only he had once hinted he thought I did not make Show enough here in my living— That he, Harris had told him I lived to the extent of my Salary; and Gallatin had said there was no chance that the Government would raise the Salaries of the Ministers abroad during the War. I have noted down the particulars of this Conversation with Harris, because they shew the character of one of the Men with whom I have been associated, and with whom it is possible I may be associated again— The public Interest requires a suppression of all the feelings of resentment which has conduct deserves; but this record may serve as a Monitor of Circumspection to myself, if I should be destined ever to act with him as a Public Servant again— His talk about Mr Gallatin to me, and before my family was often such as is not fit to be repeated— He made himself so odious to Lewis, Milligan and Todd, that they could no longer keep terms with him; and one of the most characteristic treats they told of him was, that he called in to him one day, a Black Servant to ask him what he heard Mr Todd and Mr Milligan say about him, when they were alone. One of his grounds for quarreling with Milligan, was that Milligan did not report to him what he heard said of him in the Societies that he frequented— Lewis says that one evening he threw a pack of Cards into Todd’s face—and that to save the wages of his Black Servant, he beat him to make him look out for another place— This is the man, with whom I was to live in Harmony.— Dr Beresford sent me an Edinburgh
Review; two Volumes of Crabbe’s Tales, and a letter from his Son to his Daughter, with extracts from Lord Byron’s Bride of Abydos. I read part of the Review in the Evening.

5. VII:30. Employed the day in writing to the Secretary of State— Charles came home from school— He had been sick, last Night; and was this Evening somewhat unwell.— I am not well myself but continue to walk an hour and a half before dinner. There has been neither Sun, Moon nor Stars to be seen for a week— The moderate weather and the gloom always come together. My Astronomical and Mathematical reading continues totally suspended.

6. VII:30. Attended to Charles’s lessons. Read prayers for the 5th: Sunday after the Epiphany— I should have been for Septuagesima Sunday— Also Massillon’s Sermon upon the misfortune of the Great who abandon God; and I continued writing letters for Mr Harris— He dined with us— Mr Smith dined at Mr Lewis’s— Received from Count Romanzoff the Passports and Packets for Mr Harris— Mr Gisborne and Miss Sally Krehmer were married the Evening before last, by Dr: Beresford.

7. VIII— I took Charles this morning to school— Mr Harris came and introduced to me, Mr Dobell; an Irishman who resided several years at Philadelphia, and who now comes from China— He has travelled over land, from Kamtschatka, upwards of 10,000 miles—sometimes on foot; carrying his baggage upon his back; sometimes floating down a river upon a raft; sometimes drawn over the snow by dogs; and sometimes by Rein-Deer— Having experienced 37 degrees of Cold by Reaumur’s Thermometer; which he says is sometimes -45 at Irkutsk in Siberia— He left Canton in January 1812. and Kamtschatka in January 1813.— He is going, if he can obtain the permission, to the Emperor’s Head-Quarter’s. I asked him what was the name of the present Emperor of China— He said it was Kai-King, a Son of Kien-Long, and a very unworthy Representative of that excellent Monarch— That he has been ten or eleven years on the throne, and that since he reigns the Revolts among the People of the Provinces have become more frequent; and the Pirates on the rivers, more numerous and formidable than they had ever been before— Mr Dobell said he had once been completely plundered, himself, by Pirates, under the command of a woman; and at another time had saved himself from others only by hard fighting.

8. V. Mr Harris called upon me this morning, and again in the Evening, when he took leave of us previous to his departure, which he has fixed for to-morrow-Morning.— I was engaged in writing, all the first part of the day, and at last answered a letter which I have had nearly three years upon file, from Mr Erving of Philadelphia.— Mr Harris left with me the original Papers concerning the Hector and the Commerce; and the Sally, which last were left with him by Mr Kimball.— This Evening I finished reading Dr: Rush’s book on the diseases of the Mind— It is not very profound or philosophical— His classification is not very distinct, nor his nomenclature well composed— The practice of drawing general conclusions from particular facts sometimes leads him to the borders of the ludicrous— But the Book though on a melancholy subject is entertaining; full of curious facts, and containing many ingenious remarks.

9. VIII. Sent Mr Harris this morning the letter for Mr: Erving which was not ready last Evening— At Noon I went with Mr: Smith to the Palace, and attended the Empress Mother’s Court— It was the Grand Duke Michel’s Birth-day, and after the Court, the Grand-Duke’s held a Circle. They are going to the Emperor’s Head-Quarters, but are afraid of arriving too late. They are to leave this City the 17th: of this month.— The Court was the thinnest and most deserted that I ever attended— Lord Walpole was the only other foreign Minister there; and was so much out of humour that he asked Mr Narishkin, the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies, between the Court and the Circle, how much longer we should have to wait; and told him that he was sorry he had not taken yesterday’s Conservateur Impartial in his Pocket; as he had not read it— The Duke de Serra-Capriola, and the Chevalier Bardaxi sent their excuses— How Count Maistre came to be absent was unaccountable.— There was much Conversation about Count Romanzoff, and much exultation at his fallen condition— Jouffroy said that he regretted it personally, because he had always treated him well— Lord Walpole said he regretted it because he gave good dinners; and that was the only regret he had about it— I mentioned to Lord Walpole that I had heard Lord Castlereagh had written to Mr Monroe, proposing a direct Negotiation; and had been gratified to hear it— He said he believed Castlereagh had written, in consequence of what he himself had written to him from this place after his arrival here— I asked Lord Walpole what Relation he was to the Lord Orford of Strawberry-Hill—he said his Relation was by the female side— That his Grandmother was a daughter of Sir Robert Walpole’s, and sister to Horace Walpole— Mr Schmidt, Mr Harris’s Clerk, came this Evening with some papers, and told me that Mr Harris took his
departure at 5 O’Clock this afternoon. Having now again a prospect of some leisure, I resumed the occupation of arranging my papers, and this Evening began upon that of bringing my Account Books into order— I have warnings not to neglect this duty, and with very earnest dispositions to keep Books and Accounts perfectly regular I have not succeeded in doing it— My long absences from my own Country have not been the only obstacles to my plans of order— My system of Book-keeping has been defective— Among my purposes is that of recommending a better one to my children.

10. V:30. I attempted to resume this morning the Essay upon Chronology, which I had busied myself with the last Winter; but on looking over what I had written I was so dissatisfied with it, that I hesitate about taking any more trouble with it— The Remainder of the day I was altogether employed in the endeavour to set my affairs in order— The morning I devoted to the Assortment of Papers, and the Evening to my Books of Accounts— I have before me still about two days work with the Papers, and at least three weeks with the Books.— This Evening there was about half an hour of clear sky, which enabled me to discover the Constellation of the Hare immediately under Orion; but nothing else— There have been only a few hours of Sunshine or Star-light since I have had Bode’s Charts.

11. VI. I recurred again this morning to my observations upon Chronology, to which I made some addition, and which I shall endeavour to revise— Began also to make from Bode’s Charts a Catalogue of the Stars of the second Magnitude. Proceeded with the Assortment of my Papers, and finished that of Letters, Dispatches, and Miscellaneous Manuscripts. In the Evening I continued the posting of my Account-Books.— Received from the Minister of the Interior, Mr Kosodawlew a letter with Papers respecting the Patent for Mr Fulton.

12. VI. After Charles came home from school I rode out in the sledge, which occasioned a painful return of rhumatism. Paid a visit to Mr: Dobell at his lodgings at the Hotel de Londres, and to the Minister of the Interior Kosodawlew. Neither of them was at home. I left at the Ministers an Answer to the letter he wrote me Yesterday. I also called to see the Chevalier Bardaxi-Azara, whom I found still greatly distressed at his loss— Countess Golovine, and the Princess de Tarente were with him, but soon went away— He has two children; a daughter nearly five and a boy not quite three years old. The daughter was with him— His intention is to return to Spain— After calling at the Silversmith’s shops, I came home, chilled untill the Evening, when we had visits from Messrs: de Tracy and de Castres. Mr Hurd called upon me this morning; and told me, that he intended to go with Mr Von Sassen to Gothenburg, and thence should proceed by the way of England, or directly as soon as possible, to America— He asked me to obtain for him a Courier’s Passport, and said he expected to be ready to go, next Friday— I asked him to call again two days before he should go, and promised to apply for a Passport for him.

13. VII. Read prayers for Sexagesima Sunday, and Massillon’s Sermon upon the Humanity due from the great, towards the People. Went with Mrs Adams and Charles to visit the new married couple at Mr Krehmer’s—Mr and Mrs Gisborne— They were gone out; and we only saw Mrs Krehmer.— Charles kept me engaged the whole Evening in hearing him read; and it always happens that when he is at home from school, my time is lost to every thing else.

14. VI:45. The festival of the Purification of the Virgin Mary, and a Holiday at Mr: Fishwick’s school. Charles being of course at home engrossed almost entirely the day. As I am returning to Chronology and Astronomy I compared the Tropical Year, and Synodial Month as given by Schubert and Biot— The tropical year according to Biot is 365.242264. days, which in the sexagesimal Calculation he gives as 365D. 5H 48M 51.6.S.— Schubert gives it 365:5:48:48. Three seconds & six tenths shorter. Schubert makes the Synodial Moon 29D 12H 44M. 2.8187.S = Biot makes it 29.530588 Days, the difference between which is not 1/30 of a Second.— The Calculation by days and decimal parts of a day is more easy and convenient than that by hours, minutes and Seconds— I computed the Period of 223 Moons with that of 18 years and 11 days, which is said to bring round the same succession of Eclipses; and found, assuming Biot’s Year and Month that the Moon completes this Revolution in 57 minutes 4 Seconds 13:9:7:12. less time than the Sun. Of course the Succession of Eclipses cannot be, as it is not uniformly the same.— In the Evening I gave about two hours to my Account-Books. Mr Lewis spent the latter part of it with us, from 9 untill 12 O’Clock— He read us part of a letter from Captain Bates, dated at Riga, giving an Account of the difficulties Messrs: Gallatin and Bayard met with there and upon the road.

15. VII:15. Took Charles to school; and walked over the river home— The thermometer which since the commencement of the present moon has scarcely ever been below -10 was this morning near 0, and there was a prospect of a thaw.— It fell however in the Evening to -10, and the sky became partly clear. There has usually been a diplomatic Circle at Court this day; but it has been this year omitted. I made out part of a list of the Stars of the second magnitude from Bode’s Uranographia, and in the Evening continued my work upon my Account Books.

16. V:30. The sky this morning was partly clear, but the twilight had already commenced when I rose— I saw from my chamber windows Arcturus, Spica, the Northern Crown, and the two principal stars of Libra.— Below the crown and nearly in the same Meridian, were two clusters of Stars, which upon referring to Bode’s Charts I found belonged to the Serpent of Ophiuchus— The whole day was clear and cold— I saw the Sun set, and perceived Venus in less than ten minutes afterwards. I expected a bright Evening, and hoped to ascertain several of the Evening Constellations; but within half an hour after dinner the sky was overclouded and nothing to be seen— So I turned my employment of the remaining hours to my Account-Books— Mr Dobell paid me a visit this morning; he had been presented to the two Grand-Dukes, who are to leave the City, early to-morrow Morning to go to the Emperor’s Head-quarters. Mrs Adams began the copying of Papers for me; for her amusement, and much to my assistance.

17. VI. Confined, the whole day to the house by the Snow. Charles came home from school, where during the remainder of the week they have Holidays— These days of idleness amount in this Country to nearly one half the time. I made Charles read and cypher at home—but this engrosses my time, and diverts me from the occupations, to which I incline— My Account Books take large and increasing portions of the Evening, and I find them in more disorder than I had foreseen. Mr Lewis spent part of the Evening with us— He told us, that Mr Hurd had the fever and would not be able to go away at present, but that Mr Von Sassen would go for England the day after to-morrow or the next day— The Grand-Dukes Nicholas and Michael went away this morning.

18. VI:30. I received a Note from Mr Hurd, informing me that he should probably not go with Mr Van Sassen— I prepared my letters to go by this Gentleman, and wrote to Mr Gallatin at Amsterdam by the Mail— Took Charles to see the Shows upon the river; this being the Maslanitza or butter-week, the Russian Carnaval, or half-lent— It is so called because their law allows them during this week to eat butter, but not flesh—and it is a week of Holidays— The cold was so severe that we could go only to one of the Booths where we saw the Rope-dancers and Tumblers— The Thermometer was at -15. and the wind blowing almost a gale— But Charles though he had been unwell last Night did not utter a complaint about the cold. His eagerness for the Sport was his fire— Continued this Evening the review of my Accounts.

19. VI:15. The thermometer this Morning at -21. Mr Lewis came to inform me that Mr: Van Sassen would not go before Monday—perhaps not untill Tuesday.— But as I had made up my dispatches and letters to go by him, Mr Lewis took them with him. He mentioned to me that great Battle at Brienne the 31st: of January and 1st: of this Month which ended in the total defeat of Napoleon and the French Army— He was here again in the Evening with a confirmation of the news. I received a Notification from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies, Narishkin, of a Te Deum at the Cazan Church, to-morrow morning, for this Event. After Charles’s morning lesson I went with him again to see the Shows on the River.— We saw three of them— The Puppet Show—the Chinese Shadows, and a second set of Rope-dancers and Tumblers, with the man of three hands and one leg— His right leg and foot are deformed—shaped like an arm and hand— He can use them as such, but walks with a crutch. The crowd of People on the river and quay was very great— The procession of sledges extended nearly to the Statue of Peter the Great, on the Isaac’s Square, and all the Booth’s more full of Spectators than I ever saw them before. The portion of the Evening which I had to my self I applied to the review of my Accounts— A work which I find will engage me nearer six weeks than three— That is, all the remnant of this Winter, untill I can walk again in the Evening.

20. V:30. Charles’s cheeks were partly frozen yesterday in going upon the river, and he was this day unwell— All his lessons were omitted. At 11. this morning I went with Mr Smith and attended the Te Deum. It was preceded by a Mass, much to the annoyance of Lord Walpole, who told the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies that their Religious Services were diaboliquement longs. The relation of the Victory at Brienne was contained in a letter from the Emperor to his Mother, which the Minister
of War Gortschakoff read before the Te Deum commenced. It concluded by saying that the allied army was in the direct march upon Paris, a word which he pronounced with a strong emphasis— Count Maistre said—il a mis un bon accent sur Paris—and Lord Walpole answered J’espere qu’on y mettra bientot une bonne Main. After returning home I read prayers for Quinquagesima Sunday, and Massillon’s Paraphrase of the 13th. Psalm, and his Sermon upon the characters of the greatness of Christ—a greatness of Holiness—of Mercy—of Perpetuity— I walked out before dinner, and saw the procession of Sledges and Carriages round the Palace Corner and Square, and the crowds of People upon the River, which were uncommonly great. The Empress mother was in the Procession; and the Hand-Bill announcing the march of the allied armies upon Paris, was circulating eagerly among the crowd.— Mr Montreal spent part of the Evening with us— Feeling deeply the situation of his Country, and seeking sources of hope and consolation in a disbelief of the accounts published here—the last straw of drowning men.

21. VII. Took Charles to school this morning and walked home. Gave the morning to enquiries of Chronology and Astronomy, and the Evening to my Accounts— I am making out a list of Stars of the second magnitude, from Bode’s Uranographia. But the sky continues inaccessible to observation. The Sun was visible this morning, and a few of the Stars in the Evening; but so obscured by a fog, that nothing could be observed.

22. V:30. I intended to resume this morning the reading of Biot’s Astronomie Physique, which has been nearly two Months laid aside; but I got engaged with the number of the Edinburg Review sent me by Dr Beresford, and the Memoirs of Alfieri, and the Correspondence of Madame du Deffand and of Mlle: de Lespinasse, brought the hour of Breakfast before I was aware— The rest of the day, I abandoned, to the Catalogue of Stars, to the Chronology, and in the Evening to my Accounts. I began the second Draft of a Chronological Dissertation; before finishing the first; which is the most chaotic thing that I ever wrote— At the close of the Evening the sky was so clear that a part of the Milky way was discernible— I could distinguish Stars of the fifth magnitude; but ascertained only the Cor Caroli 2. the hunting dogs, and the Hair of Berenice.

23. VII. The Stars, Chronology and my Accounts still occupy all my time— The day and Evening were perfectly clear and gave me a good opportunity to survey the parts of the skies that can be seen from my Windows— I recognized the Hydra’s head and heart— The two Aselli of Cancer with the nebula between them, the little Lion; the paws of Ursa Major— Vindemiatrix and the other Stars of the third Magnitude in Virgo— The knee of Cepheus, and Frederic’s Sword. These with the Constellations that I knew before are nearly all that I can find out at present. For I fully ascertained that with my eye and glass I can perceive no stars smaller than of the 5th: magnitude— There are four of the 6th: in the form of a diamond in the middle of the Square at the Lion’s Back,—but I could not discern one of them.— I received this morning a Note from Count Romanzoff; a Circular to the foreign Ministers informing them that being unable by reason of ill-health to perform for the present the duties of the Department of foreign affairs, he requests them in future to address their official Communications to the Senator Weidemeyer, a member of the Department, untill the Emperor shall make known his determination.— I suppose this is to foreclose the mortification of any further notice of his dismission. I sent a short answer to his Note, and presume that this will close all my diplomatic relations with him. They have all been so far as depended upon him of a pleasing Nature— I esteem and respect his character, and consider the loss of his Counsels as a serious loss to this Empire.

24. V:45. The morning was clear; but the dawn was already so far advanced when I rose that the few Stars to be seen were faint and dim, and there was nothing new to be seen— The Evening was lucid at intervals. I found the knees and feet of the twins, and the eye of the Unicorn (Monoceros) between the right shoulder of Orion and Procyon. Attended a new sale of Books at Grabit’s, and the rest of the day was employed with Bode’s Uranographia, Petau, Chronology, and my Account Books.

25. V.15. The weather continues fine, and the sky as clear as it can ever be expected in this climate— I surveyed as much as I can see of them from my house, and reviewed almost every star that I have hitherto discovered.— I found none new, but ascertained the side and left foot of Perseus, the head of Medusa, the foot and girdle of Andromeda; the armpits and knees of Bootes, and Mount Maenalus at his feet. I have hitherto fought in vain for the square of Pegasus, and the Dolphin— They are in the Evening below the horizon, or so near it as to be concealed by its vapours— The Swan’s tail,
and Lyra never set. Jupiter hangs “like a rich Jewel in an Ethiop’s ear” between the Lion’s heart and tail; but the most magnificent object of the Night is the great square of Orion, with his splendid vicinity of Sirius, Procyon Aldebaran, the Twins, and the Pleiades, moving majestically along, as they pass in the Meridian before my chamber windows, now between 7 and 10 in the Evening— Manilius very justly remarks that a man who does not know this Constellation need give himself no trouble about any others— I attended the sale of Books this day but made no purchase— The sets of Volumes, are almost all incomplete. In the intervals of my star-gazing this Evening we played a Rubber of whist.

26. Having been last Evening untill near Midnight searching for Stars, it was this morning seven O’Clock when I rose; and my eyes begin to be more than weary of this pursuit— But while the weather continues so clear I cannot allow the opportunity to escape— For the same reason, I walked an hour this Evening after dinner— The first time this year— As yesterday was the first time we sat down to dinner, before the candles were brought— In my walk I examined the sky as much as I could conveniently; but the Moon is near quartering, and was too bright to suffer many of the Stars to be seen— The square of Pegasus was still invisible— My occupations during the day are constant, and fill every moment of my time— I attend the sale of Books as a relaxation, and to give a respite to my eyes.— Charles came home from school— Mrs Adams had a visit from Countess Colombi, who told her that Baroness Koscull, alias Mrs Hall, had commenced prophetess, or fortune-teller; and foretold so much that the Grand Master of the Police, Gorgoly had paid her a visit, and advised her not to be so knowing.

27. III. I rose at this early hour to have the benefit of seeing clear sky without Moon-light— I was able just to discern two of the Stars of the sixth Magnitude in the Lion— I spent two full hours at the chamber windows on both sides of the house, and besides all my former celestial acquaintance recognized the Crow, Hercules, the Head of Ophiuchus, and the star of the second magnitude in the first claw of the Scorpion, from my own chamber; and the Dolphin and Antinoüs from the front side of the house— The head, and folds of the Serpent of Ophiuchus down to the two Stars at his hands I saw very distinctly— I might have seen Antares, by going into the Street; but it was too cold— At 5 the day dawned and all the Stars of less than the first magnitude vanished while I was seeking for the square of Pegasus— At precisely 7 the Sun rose— And from this time I shall have no inclination to inspect morning stars, at least before another Winter. Six days and Nights in succession of clear weather are so rare in occurrence in this Country that I am not to expect it soon again— In the course of this day the Clouds returned and this Evening there was nothing to be seen— I saw Venus last Night as Evening Star— She is in a very few days to become the Morning Star— A change which I should be glad to observe, but of which there is little chance at this Season.— I read prayers this day for Quadragesima Sunday, or the first Sunday in Lent, and Massillon’s Sermon upon the Vanity of human glory. Made Charles a Letter-Book, to keep copies of his Letters and employed him in writing part of a Letter to his brother George— This exercise is more agreeable to himself than writing Copies, and more useful to him— He takes more pains with the writing, and considers it less of a task— It employs his thoughts and entertains his affections for his brothers, and I hope will have a like effect upon them, towards him— It is an excellent exercise of spelling as well as of writing, and it accustoms his mind to habits of order, which cannot be too soon instilled into children— I pray for the blessing of Heaven that the success may answer to my intentions. I continued my Chronological Dissertation, with painful efforts to disentangle its confusion. I am extremely dissatisfied with what I have written, but at all Events must get through. My rhumatism affects my head again; and it stupifies my intellect.— Having risen so early this morning, I made the Evening short in proportion, and retired immediately after nine.

28. V.15. And laboured at my Chronological Dissertation for George, untill the time came for taking Charles to school. I went with him, and then called upon Mr Meyer to enquire if he knew whether the Bill on London which I sent last Summer to make a remittance to Quinzard’s brother had been paid— He did not know— The letters were sent to Amsterdam, and had been forwarded thence to Paris.— He had received no acknowledgment from Hottinger and Co: of their having been received. The accounts of their Correspondents in London upon whom the Bills were drawn were made up yearly to 31. March, and when those of the present year arrive, it will appear whether the Bill was paid— I also made some further arrangement concerning the funds of mine, which Meyer and Bruxner have in their hands.— Mr Montreal paid me a morning, and
Mr de Tracy an Evening visit— They are still deeply affected by the situation of their Country; and flattering themselves with hopes which a very few days will prove to be delusive.

Day— The irregularity of my rising hour, continues as heretofore; and as it arises principally from the state of my health, will probably never be corrected. The difference in this Month as the last ranges from three to eight, and the average is about six. In the course of the Month I have written more and read less than the preceding Months— Bode’s Charts and Petau have absorbed much of my time, but my Astronomical and Mathematical reading has still been totally suspended.
